awd_titl_txt: Austin College's Career Empowering STEM Scholars
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to remain vital, the American economy must compete globally, attract investment, and develop the STEM workforce.  This NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project will provide scholarships for 16 students and provide enhanced support structures to all students (approximately 600) with STEM career goals, thus increasing their chances of academic and employment success.  Additionally, the scholarship recipients will be exposed to career exploration opportunities in biology, biochemistry, chemistry, computer science, mathematics and physics through connections to local STEM employers, formalized career preparation opportunities, and job placement services.  A key feature of the project will be the scholars' participation in a STEM leadership program that promotes the development of interpersonal communication, problem solving, collaborative work, foresight and planning, and moral consciousness skills.

Research suggests that norms in higher educational settings typically emphasize independence and may be alienating to students who come from groups that emphasize interdependence.  This project will investigate the role that the development of interdependent skills in the context of STEM has in promoting academic success generally, and success in STEM specifically among academically talented, low-income students.  Interdependent skills will be nurtured through participation in the STEM leadership program and be reinforced through cohort meetings and individual mentoring.  The PI team hypothesizes that making these interdependent skills a central part of professional development in STEM may foster the persistence and success of all students; particularly those eligible for S-STEM scholarships.  Formative and summative evaluation will include collecting data related retention and graduation rates and surveys on the effectiveness of the graduate school and career preparation activities.  Results from the project will be disseminated via education journals such as the Journal of Higher Education, Journal of College Science Teaching, and Journal of Research in Science Teaching and at conferences specific to each STEM major like the American Association of Physics Teachers meetings, Biennial Conference of Chemical Educators, among others.

por.por_cntn:
Austin College's Career Empowering STEM Scholars (ACCESS) Program successfully recruited 29 academically talented students with demonstrated financial need into STEM programs at Austin College. This four-year program retained 27 of the 29 students at Austin College, and 23 of 26 students graduated within four years (the 27th student is currently a rising senior and on track to graduate within four years). The ACCESS Program had 20 of the 23 graduated participants continue to STEM-focused graduate school programs or career paths in STEM fields. The four remaining participants are actively applying to STEM-focused graduate programs as they finish their final year, or they intend a career path in STEM.

 

As a small liberal arts college, Austin College commits considerable support to providing students the opportunity to participate in an undergraduate research experience or a credit-bearing off-campus internship experience in STEM. A total of 22 of 27 students took advantage of these opportunities (>80%), and several program participants gained full-time employment at their internship sites following graduation. ACCESS Program participants presented their research experiences at local, regional, or national conferences with several receiving travel awards and/or awards for presentation. Related to their work, ACCESS scholars are coauthored on three manuscripts published in peer-reviewed journals. Additionally, one ACCESS Program participant was nationally recognized as a Goldwater Scholar.

 

Intellectual Merit: The Austin College ACCESS Program empowered Austin College to design, implement, assess, and advance practices that support STEM student success. The project included both innovative and evidence-based support structures and strategies to prepare academically talented students with demonstrated financial need for successful futures in STEM graduate programs and careers.

 

Broader Impact: The Austin College ACCESS Program prepared STEM graduates for success in STEM-focused graduate programs and career paths. ACCESS also supported STEM graduates from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields. Fully two-thirds of the Scholars are female, and 16 of the 27 participants identify as Hispanic or Black. Once in the workforce, this increased number of STEM role models can support and mentor younger members of these communities in the future and encourage them to pursue careers in STEM.

 


Last Modified: 07/20/2023
Modified by: David P Aiello
